awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Bridging Self-Organized and Algorithmic Approaches to Multi-Robot Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project consists of research to address the limitations of traditional ways of programming groups of robots in order to make it easier to program them to solve problems in teams.  The work is helping realize a future where robots address important applications such as those with life-saving, ecological, and national strategic elements (e.g., manufacturing, roboticized agriculture, planetary exploration). To do this, the research is establishing new connections between methods developed for thinking about very large data sets, mathematical models invented by physicists for small-scale phenomena, and today's robot swarms.  One particular task being explored is the feasibility of managing carbon sequestration with minimal human intervention; if successfully scaled up this could have a huge positive impact ecologically, improving quality-of-life globally.

Over the last couple of decades, two disparate perspectives have come to dominate thinking about multi-robot systems, each perspective or  paradigm having its own philosophy, tools, models, and even publication venues.  The idea being explored by this research is that the existing separation of the paradigms is vestigial, arising out of early AI questions about representation, and that for progress to be made it is essential that methods and tools accommodate systems that mix the characteristics of both paradigms.  The work is improving scalability, performance, robustness, and model predictability for multi-robot systems by bridging and consolidating the paradigms along two thrusts. The first introduces and establishes a new position in the space between the paradigms with a new class of distributed algorithms that extend techniques for sublinear time approximation to communication settings with message-passing.  The second thrust develops and applies theory that spans the established boundaries by applying renormalization group transformation methods to characterize multi-scale system behavior.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Picture your favorite sports team for a moment. If they're any good, they likely have potent communication abilities so that the players form an effective decision-making unit; their success probably mixes deliberation (think of the players forming a huddle to strategize) with responses that react spontaneously to specific opportunities. Robots (and other AI agents) when part of a coordinated group also need to act in a cohesive fashion and these two modes of behavior ?deliberation and planning vs reflex and reaction? both play vital roles in how we program robot teams and swarms.  Over the period of this NSF award, we have been studying the interplay of these two modes of behavior, examining the ways in which they are complimentary, situations for which one might be more important than the other, and fresh ways they might be combined. We've done this by exploring how to build and program robot groups for a variety of tasks that are not only societally useful (in terms of how we might put robots to productive work, e.g., via navigation or object transportation) but also interesting in how they demonstrate the impact of the interplay. 

A specific example of such an interplay is when one group of robots that is flocking (based on rules hypothesized to fit some biological systems) is corralled or shepherded by another group. The first figure shows how a group of three robots, by coordinating their placement, are causing the environment to seem like one with an obstructing barrier. This allows a small number of capable robots (here three) to manipulate a larger collection (here admittedly only four) of simpler agents, the latter employing no sophisticated deliberation at all.

Notice how in the previous example, the functionality of the shepherding group can be described simply (e.g., they are form a barrier) at a high level of abstraction. That same pattern holds in another example too. In the second figure, there are 4 photos showing the progression of an experiment in which a pair of robots work together to move circular objects to a rectangular goal region. These robots have a type of tail that they can use to drag objects. The tail is a custom design that means they are able to link or un-link themselves, and this gives the robots two quite distinct ways to transport objects. They can either fetch objects individually or, instead, can form a closely-knit pair by linking tails and then skim a wide area. The photos shows how the robots solve a particular problem: they first fetch two objects that lie quite far out, and then link tails to scoop up the remainder. Here they have precise motions for linking and un-linking tails, but then they are simply acting like one scoop. When the plan to solve the problem, they decide when to act alone, and also when they need to pay closer attention to have fine-grained coordination. One paper produced during this research project even has the title; "When to Do Your Own Thing..."

This project has studied how to bridge deliberative and self-organized approaches effectively. The core focus has been on improving scalability, performance, robustness, and the predictability of models for multi-robot systems through hybrid approaches, and the project's successes have been achieved by connecting models, tools, and approaches. These and other insights have made their way into the classroom in a number of courses that the principal investigator has taught. They've also been explicated to lab visitors (including tour groups, school children, and high school teachers). Graduate students who received funds from the NSF through this project have gone on to become professors and to teach students of their own.


Last Modified: 12/23/2022
Modified by: Dylan A Shell

Images (1 of )
  • A deliberative system of three mobile robots coordinates to form a barrier in the environment so as to dynamically shepherd a self-organized group of four that are flocking.
    Dylan Shell
    Creative Commons
    Dylan A Shell
    Groups of robots navigating an small environment.
  • Four images showing the progression of an experiment as two robots with tailscoordinate in transporting circular objects. They represent the following times: [Top left] 70 seconds; [Top right] 106 seconds; [Bottom left] 160 seconds; [Bottom right] 210 seconds.
    Young-Ho Kim and Dylan Shell
    Creative Commons
    Dylan A Shell
    Four snapshots of a pair of robots with tails moving objects to a central location.
